title: RS22055
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) provides federal funding for children with disabilities to receive a free appropriate public education (FAPE). It includes due process provisions and attorneys' fees, added in 1986, to ensure FAPE for all children with disabilities. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) includes provisions for attorneys' fees, added in 1986 by the Handicapped Children's Protection Act. Amendments in 1997 allowed for the reduction of attorneys' fees if specific information about the child and dispute basis was not provided to the LEA. The Handicapped Children's Protection Act added provisions for attorneys' fees in 1986, with amendments in 1997 allowing for fee reduction if specific information is not provided to the LEA. The 2004 law had different approaches in the House and Senate bills regarding attorneys' fees. The 2004 law on attorneys' fees for individualized education plan (IEP) meetings had different approaches in the House and Senate bills. The final reauthorization was closer to the Senate version, allowing attorneys' fees for state educational purposes. The 2004 IDEA reauthorization, closer to the Senate version, included changes to attorneys' fees provisions. Senator Grassley and Senator Gregg emphasized the need to prevent abuses of due process rights in IDEA and ensure taxpayer dollars go towards educating children. Senator Gregg emphasized the need for an attorneys' fee amendment to prevent abuses of due process rights in IDEA and ensure taxpayer dollars are used for educating children, not for trial lawyers' fees. This concept has been applied in title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Senator Gregg highlighted the importance of the attorneys' fee amendment, citing the precedent set in title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 where prevailing defendants can recover fees if a plaintiff's actions are deemed frivolous, unreasonable, or without foundation. The standard is high, making it rare for prevailing defendants to meet and obtain fees. The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission stated that prevailing defendants should be able to recover attorneys' fees if a plaintiff's actions are frivolous, unreasonable, or without foundation to protect them from baseless litigation. Senator Gregg noted that prevailing defendants rarely meet the high standard required to obtain fee reimbursement and that courts consider the plaintiff's financial resources when awarding fees. The Department of Education stated that non-attorney advocates are not entitled to compensation as attorneys, citing a Supreme Court decision that explicit language authorizing recovery of experts' fees by prevailing parents was not included in the 2004 reauthorization of IDEA. The Supreme Court decision in Arlington Central School District Board of Education v. Murphy stated that explicit language authorizing recovery of experts' fees by prevailing parents must be included in legislation. The Department of Education declined to add a regulatory provision on this issue for non-attorney experts.
